Expectation1: Look out for each other's safety and well-being
Situation1: One sibling is preparing to try a new skateboard trick on a steep, uneven ramp.
Situation2: The partner is grieving the sudden loss of a close family member.
Story:
I stood at the edge of the skate park, my heart pounding as I watched my stepbrother tighten his helmet, eyes fixed on the steep, cracked ramp. He grinned at me, eager to show off the new trick he’d been practicing. I knew he wanted my encouragement, but all I could see was the risk—the uneven concrete, the way he’d limped home last time. I was supposed to look out for him, to keep him safe, but he hated when I hovered or told him to stop.

My phone buzzed in my pocket. It was my boyfriend, his messages raw with grief. He needed me, needed my comfort, my words, my presence. I could almost hear his voice, shaky and lost, asking if I could come over. I wanted to be there for him, to hold him and let him cry, to be the support he desperately needed.

But I couldn’t be in two places at once. My stepbrother was already rolling toward the ramp, and my boyfriend’s pain pressed at me through the screen. I felt torn in half, pulled by love and responsibility, unable to choose without letting someone down.
